_usage: Copy commands below into your ~/.claude/commands.json file under the 'commands' key

/psl-journal.prompt:
Create a journal entry using PS-LANG syntax in .ps-lang/journal/{{date}}-{{topic}}.psl

Structure:
- Human-readable summary at top
- PS-LANG zone annotations throughout
- AI metadata at bottom
- Follow the template in .ps-lang/templates/journal-template.psl

Topic: {{prompt}}

Use appropriate zones:
- <@.> for active tasks
- <#.> for documentation
- <.> for private notes
- <~.> for AI-generated metadata

/psl-log.prompt:
Create a technical log using PS-LANG syntax in .ps-lang/logs/{{date}}-{{topic}}.psl

Structure:
- Technical summary at top
- Performance metrics
- PS-LANG zone annotations
- Benchmarking data at bottom
- Follow the template in .ps-lang/templates/log-template.psl

Topic: {{prompt}}

Include:
- Processing statistics
- Context reduction metrics
- Agent handoff protocol

/psl-zones.prompt:
Display all available PS-LANG zones from .ps-lang/config/ps-lang.config.json with:

1. Zone syntax (e.g., <@.>, <#.>)
2. Description of each zone
3. Example usage
4. When to use it

Format as a quick reference guide.

/psl-validate.description: Validate PS-LANG syntax in current file
/psl-validate.prompt:
Validate PS-LANG syntax in the current file:

1. Check for properly closed zones
2. Identify any syntax errors
3. Verify zone nesting (if applicable)
4. Suggest improvements

Report:
- Valid zones found
- Any errors or warnings
- Syntax score (0-100%)

_integration_steps: 4. Save and restart Claude Code if needed
